full_title_en: HIV Needle Stick Risk Assessment Stratification Protocol (RASP)
medium_description_en: Quantifies HIV exposure risk by source and exposure type and need for prophylaxis.
short_description_en: Quantifies exposure risk, need for prophylaxis.

seo.meta_description_en: The HIV Needle Stick Risk Assessment Stratification Protocol (RASP) Quantifies HIV exposure risk by source and exposure type and need for prophylaxis.
seo.keywords_en: HIV Needle Stick Risk Assessment Stratification Protocol (RASP), HIV, PEP protocol, RASP, needle stick, HIV needle, hiv stick, HIV RASP, HIV PEP, hiv pep, hiv risk, hiv s/p needle stick, hiv needle stick protocol, HIV Needle Stick RASP, needle stick rasp

how_to_use.use_case_en:
• High vs low risk exposure; helps determine whether or not to start PEP.
  • Always try to test the source patient for HIV, and other infectious diseases such as Hepatitis C and Hepatitis B.
how_to_use.why_use_en: The HIV Needle Stick Risk Assessment Protocol quantifies gives healthcare workers a more objective risk assessment of getting HIV after a needle stick.

next_steps.advice_en: If indicated, PEP should be started in conjunction with infectious disease consultation, as well as gathering information about the source patient and his or her medication regimen.

about.formula_en:
Basic risk = 1 / (Source population x Inoculum type x Method of transmission)

 

Total risk = Basic risk x Volume of inoculum

 

Where variables are as follows:

Variable

Points

Source population*

Known HIV+: acute AIDS illness

1

10

Unknown HIV status: high-risk situation

100

1000

Fresh blood

1

10

100

Low-risk secretions (e.g., tears, urine, saliva)

1000

Method of transmission

Intravenous

1

Deep intramuscular

10

Deep transcutaneous with visible bleeding

100

Superficial transcutaneous without bleeding

200

Mucosal contact only

500

Intact skin

1000

Volume of inoculum

Massive (e.g., transfusion)

100

Measurable (>1 mL)

10

Moderate (large-bore, hollow needle >22 g)

5

Small (small-bore, hollow needle <22 g)

3

Trace surface only (e.g., suture needle)

1

*Acute AIDS illness defined as “end stage AIDS, hospitalized, high viral load”. Unknown HIV status, high-risk situation defined as “suspected HIV, IV drug user, unknown needle with high local HIV prevalence”.

creator_info.about_en: Les Vertesi, MD, is the executive director of British Columbia's Health Services Purchasing Organization and a part-time emergency room physician. He is on the faculty of Simon Fraser University's Institute for Health Research and Education and is associate director of Health Research with the Fraser Health Authority of British Columbia. Dr. Vertesi published a book in 2003: Broken Promises: The Trouble with Canadian Medicare...and How to Fix it.
